In our experiments, the failure of interleukin-10-/- mice to more effectively eliminate i.c. bacteria correlated with lower i.c. frequencies of L. monocytogenes-specific CD8+ T cells in their brains while the favorable prognosis of interleukin-10+/+ mice was associated with increased frequencies of these cells. These findings indicate that the regulatory activity of interleukin-10 is crucial for focusing the i.c. immune response on antigen-specific CD8+ T-cell responses, which is in agreement with recent studies illustrating that interleukin-10 favors the development of antigen-specific T cells, in particular CD8+ T cells (9, 15, 30, 31, 42, 43).
